reviewText:
This movie is the kind of melodrama that one doesn't see in feature films anymore. It is about a woman with dissociative personality disorder (see 1957's The Three Faces of Eve). Through hokey flashbacks the main character, Frankie's traumatic past is revealed with the help of a psychiatrist via hypnotherapy. Movies typically trigger a character's flashback to the past using some sort of object that was present in the past or is reminiscent of an object in the memory, but few movies are unimaginative enough to use light as this trigger. A flashlight triggers Frankie's memories because during her past traumas there were a car's front lights or even sunlight. We would all have some form of mental illness if light triggered vivid recollections of the past.

If you pay attention you will see this movie's plot points developing a mile away. One side character has a subplot shoehorned in that seems as if most of it was cut from the movie. What is left of his "character development" comes across as bizarre and alienating. Almost every scene of Frankie and Alice is cliche and yet it is still watchable.

This movie currently has a 14% on Rottentomatoes. Why did no one hear about this movie, and why do those that did disparage it? It is not because americans don't like melodrama. Many of the best picture winners in recent years are melodramas, only they add some twist to the formula to make viewers feel like their seeing something new and important. The Artist is a melodrama in black and white with no sound. Slumdog Millionaire is a melodrama with Ballywood trappings. Million Dollar Baby is a melodrama with a weepy piano and violin soundtrack and laconic philosophical musings. Frankie and Alice is a melodrama completely composed of elements all movie watchers have seen many times over.

There is one good aspect to the movie but it is not the direction. There is one scene in which Frankie (Halle Berry) is experiencing multiple personality transitions and the camera stays pretty much fixed in one position for several minutes. Despite the editing and direction, which occasionally turns this melodrama into unintentional comedy, Halle Berry's very competent performance holds this film together. She shows acting chops that may have been luminous in a better film, but in this one only come across as well done acting exercises.

Watch this movie if you are in the mood for racial melodrama, or if you are a Halle Berry fan. It does not disappoint if you just want a comfortable retread of story arcs and plot points you have already seen before.

First of all don't be swayed by the 1 star one of the reviewers gave this movie.  The rating has nothing to do with the quality of the acting or storyline.  It has to do with why it has not hit the theaters or commercial DVD.  I agree it is such a disservice to those involved in the movie and to the public.  I reiterate what one of the other reviewers said. It is the best piece of acting I have seen Halle Berry in.  THIS is the movie she SHOULD have won an OSCAR for!!  Her acting is raw, human, controversal and grabs and holds you from the first moment the movie starts, until the credits begin to roll.  She plays a young women with multiple personalities, with those personalities being as different from each other as the North Pole is from the South Pole; and she plays those personalities completely believable. Phylicia Rashad, plays her mother, and Chandra Wilson (Grey's Anatomy) plays the role of her sister.  Just say that the whole family has issues. This film was made a few years ago(2010), and I wonder if it is ever going to be released in ,theaters.  Halle was interviewed about it's release a couple of years ago, and she didn't know when or if it would be released. If it doesn't get released the public would have missed an opportunity to witness the actress at her FINEST! This is a body of work she should be most proud of.

Without giving anyway the movie for those of you that actually want to be surprised and hate spoiler alerts I will say the movie does come together well. That is not the problem. When we watch movies we are looking to be entertained. Either we walk away with a moral lesson or a psychological satisfaction of having our minds challenged. We need to come away with something from the movie. I get they were trying to show that something was wrong but where is the hope at in the movie. Every movie needs hope. Although the ending was a good ending it didn't leave you with hope at the end. The movie almost just seemed like a tragedy that was being told and left at being a tragedy that was told. I get there are some bad and sad things that happen to people in life. I am prepared to hear those stories but when the movie doesn't leave me with any hope and something that I can walk away from the movie with, I almost think why waste production. We have enough movies that have been done that tell this kind of story. If the producers are not going to tell this story in such a way that a movie is the only way to tell it why spend needless money. This is not a bad movie and you will not be bored but I've seen this same story done too many times. Wish the movie would have given the audience more and told the story in such as way that you could watch this movie again and again and it would not get old.

While wonderfully acted, the writing is weak. Much time is spent focusing on the strange behavior in the present, but too little on the traumatic back story to explain her disassociations and her transitions into them. It left me wondering, is there a genotype that is prone to such a strange disorder? More time of her life as a child and young adult might have added some depth. What we mostly see are the striking different internal characters playing against each other. Also, there is too little time spent on the character's resolution. Did treatment help? What is it like with her personalities reintegrated, or did that ever happen? This is just so much empty calories sensational psychodrama that provides little insight into the human mind and what it is capable of. A final, positive personal preference note: it is always great to see Halle Berry in something other than her trademark short pixie butch cut hair style. Saved this from being only a one star rating.

Even though the ending attempted to resolve the movie and bring things full circle
in her life, and in the overall treatment. It felt very abrupt (two minutes spent on it,

killed the movie for me. Overall I thought it was pretty good, -maybe a 3 star film,
reflective of the IMDB rating (or close to it). But the ending was way to short and
felt rushed. It felt contrived. The doctor tried to gloss over and explain away an
apparent serious crime. He did this in the best interest of the patient perhaps,
who was in a fragile state, but it made for a poor resolution to the plot/script,
that they tried to fix at the very end without actually filming a scene where the audience
would learn the truth about what happened. I think a much better ending would have
been to film the scene where both the viewers and the patient learned the truth about
what happened to Alice (even though it is inferred or implied and we think we know)
where the patient (primary character) would address the potential criminal perpetrator
(a family member) and find the truth out about what that person did. If they had done
that scene and done it well, it could have been the best scene in the entire movie and
in fact could have made the entire movie. In this movie, they even could have ran
with that idea and done an alternate ending also. If they had done either and done it well,
it would be a 4 star movie.

My problem with this movie is that it perpetuates myths about DID. Dissociative Identity Disorder, formerly known as Multiple Personality Disorder, is typically a response to severe and prolonged childhood abuse. The idea of a single incident causing Frankie's personality to split is hard to swallow. While the premise is interesting, this movie seems disrespectful to people who actually have DID, and to those who struggle with mental illness in general. Mental illness is already stigmatized enough. Granted, this is a movie, but if art is an imitation of life, we should adhere to the basic facts. Even if Game of Thrones, a sword is still a sword, even if they also have direwolves.

Halle gave the kind of quality performance that only SHE'S capable of, in playing a young woman who in real life, suffered from Multiple Personality Disorder and didn't initially know it.  The storyline is well-written, with all the plots and mystery you'd expect a psych movie to have.  But like peeling an onion, you gradually get to see what traumas Frankie sadly suffered---ultimately the final one being the worst (no thanks to her Mother, played by Phylicia Rashad) which pushed Frankie over the edge into her full-blown MPD.

Halle was very convincing in all her characters; and her Psychiatrist Dr. Oz was such a wonderful man who dedicated himself to her case & selflessly took the time to genuinely help her so much, that I'm sure when he died in 2001, God had a special Blessing just waiting for him in Heaven!

The only disappointment I had, was that I would've liked to see a scene of Frankie confronting her Mother about what she did with her newborn baby when it went into some kind of distress immediately upon its birth.  I feel that absence left a hole in the storyline and I feel that the audience should have had the privilege in seeing Frankie's Mom take accountability for her improper actions---as Frankie had the legal & moral right to have closure if the baby died naturally, and IF her Mom did kill that baby, she needed to 'fess-up to it right then & there.

Other than that, I loved the movie and it's going into my favorites to watch again in the near future.  Hat's off to Halle & her great performance!!

~M Rich

Excellent flick.  Halle & Stellan are great together for one thing.  For another, the story of Frankie's journey along with her "alters" is handled as well as any story about a person with multiple personalities can be.  Starting with the challenges caused by the switching of personalities being not under her control, touched off by events in the moment linked to events from her past and the emotional shields she created to protect herself, Frankie finds that the protective interventions of the alters on the present mean she's responsible for behaviors that weigh on her conscience as wrong, besides having consequences of giving her a really bad reputation.  In other words, Frankie finds she has her hands full and when the Doctor (Stellan) begins to make inroads in explaining it all to her, she gets interested.  But the alters aren't going down easy: the original traumatic events were crushingly complex and, at least emotionally, massively perilous.  Frankie proves an elusive patient for the Doctor, who must also struggle for support from his cohorts, but Frankie eventually rises to the occasion in a touching scene.  Most interesting to me is the notion that, at least in this case, multiple personality disorder is essentially an extreme form of Complex Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.  Finally, Halle deserves an Oscar for the depth and believability of her acting the roles of the alters and of Frankie herself.  Fantastic!

Halle Berry's acting is top notch, and this movie is entertaining, but there are problems with it.  Either they left out a lot of the backstory that would enable the viewer to understand it, especially the ending, in perspective, or she doesn't have MPD.  MPD results from repetitive and severe childhood trauma. There is no evidence in this movie that the Frankie character ever had any.  In the beginning she freaks out when someone who appears to be a boyfriend with whom she has a relationship touches her, yet there is no evidence in the entire movie about why she would get upset about being touched by a man, and in fact there is evidence that she doesn't have any problem with men or with sexual contact.  Much of the movie is senseless. For example, she has a baby after her boyfriend is killed in an accident, and it appears from the movie that although the baby cries once it dies in her mother's arms. Then she alleges her mother killed it but she doesn't know why. This remains totally confusing to the viewer and unresolved.  There is nothing in this movie that would give the viewer any comprehension of why her mother would do that. Her relationship with her mother is not developed. It is clear her sister is jealous of her and doesn't approve of her lifestyle, but nobody knows why.  The doctors in the hospital are made to look like idiots, and maybe they were, because they appear to have misdiagnosed her.  She also has a personality who has the name that she and her boyfriend were going to give the baby, Alice, and that too makes no sense.  She apparently also has some serious issues with a woman she knew back in her teens but why is never explored. My guess is she had some kind of mental illness or, more likely, she was having problems caused by a history of drug use that is not revealed, not MPD, and was misdiagnosed.  Great acting, but a very confusing and poorly developed story line.

I enjoyed this movie. Halle Berry's acting was very good, she really made it look like she had three very different personalities (Frankie, Alice, Genius).

I wanted to see more backstory, of why her personality split. From what I have heard about multiple personalities, the person splits at a very young age (usually younger than 5) and it is caused by constant trauma, usually sexual abuse.

SPOILER ALERT... Frankie's trauma was that, as a teenager, she gave birth (shortly after the baby's father died in a car accident), and her mother delivered the baby in the house, and then the mother immediately ran out of the house with the baby and killed it. Of course, this is horrible, but I don't think that it could cause multiple personality disorder because it was not a continuing trauma that happened at a very early age. I see that this is a true story, and I do believe that the woman had some kind of a serious mental illness, but I do not think that she had multiple personality disorder. This story takes place in 1973, so I wonder what the diagnosis might have been today. The mother ran out of the house, into the rain at night, with the newborn in her arms and nothing else, but we don't see what happened next. Frankie says that her mother killed the baby, but she does not say how or give any details at all. Where was the sister when this happened? No one saw anything? The murder was never discovered? Did Frankie just block out the whole experience?

I admit it!  I love Halle Berry!  While I haven't seen ALL of her films, I have never seen her in one where her performance wasn't remarkable or even extraordinary (Monster's Ball, to name one).  Halle dazzles, again, in Frankie & Alice.  Her ability to believably handle a multiple personality role is mesmerizing.  In truth, I would have given this 4 1/2 stars, not 5...as I reserve 5 for those rare perfect films.  That being said, I find little fault with this film, unlike some if its harsher critics.  I was left going 'wow...she did it again'.  Halle never fails me, never disappoints me.  She is an extraordinary beauty and an extraordinary talent.  Technically, the direction, the screenplay, worked for me as well.  Intellectually, it's a look at mental illness, its potential root causes, and, most importantly, the masks it wears, often by people we may experience in our everyday lives.
